text: <!channel>: Hey Brandlab Wall team, since we’re all working from home today I’d like to have our standup via slack. So please in the next few minutes let me know your plan for today.
<@U0914MEN7|james> has left the channel
Hi Abby!
sup abby
heyyyy!!
in terms of Cubby - the main thing I’ll be working on today is this idea Joel and I had right before break which was a reverse hinge for the doors
so that they slide down instead of up
I need to work on it a little more and then pressure test it with Joel and hopefully <@U02F8LF2X> to make sure there’s a there there
but it seems important in light of the email that came through today with Ion Tank’s door test
I think we can disregard the 11inch version and probably the 40 too
but honestly none of them are ideal
Yea I agree
unless we can get a better hinge system, I think it’s worth looking at other options
I setup one of the NUC units with linux and interactive spaces, and went through the tutorials for using it. So when we are ready to start doing something in that space I'm ready there
Digging into the Tech Design Doc to capture everything we’ve been working on in writing.
@peter :clap:
@joel - do you have any thoughts vis a vis the door/hinge test?
<@U02E3CRMA>: :point_up_2:
also - <@U026103R3> - I don’t know what the plan is for felix, but he might be a helpful person to have consult on this hinge thing too
strictly from a mechanical point of view
yea agreed on the Felix idea, he should be in tomorrow and we can try to grab him

<@U0260V4K1>: just looked through all the images. Everything seems pretty cramped regardless of height. Having the screen above makes stuffing the cubby a blind operation in all but the highest standing option (63.5”), which seems to make interaction awkward at best.
agreed
I’m interested to see what we might come up with for the door dropping instead for line-of-sight
I know we ran into a bit of block on the reverse system, but I’d love to play with a little more
I'll have Felix shadowing/meeting/ramping up for tomorrow - but it'd be great to pose those sorts of questions as part of his ramp
yeah - I think it’s something he could maybe help on without needing to know the entire project
totally
let's do that tomorrow. :wink:
cool!

most of the awkwardness seems to be created from the screen being so far out from the wall. I think if we retrofitted curved arms or otherwise fiddled with the geometry, it would expand the range of acceptable heights
this type of hinge is designed to open upward not downward so it may not work if reversed
maybe be counterbalanced for only upward operation
well - I think for the reverse option, it’d be a redesigned system
but - I agree on the arms being the main problem with the current system
do you think there’s a curved arm option to be had?
<@U02F8LF2X>: if you think that’s a viable option, can you get back to them on their last email with the video of the hinge test and see what they say about curved hinges?
I already suggested that
sorry, where did we suggest it? i don’t remember their response

Thanks for this! It's neat to envision how this idea might come to life. Had a few questions (numbered for reference):

1. What are our options in terms of travel speed inches/sec for the linear actuators? 
1b. What does speed control for the linear actuators look like? PWM from a micro? Or is there some sort of prepackaged controller?
2. Seems like it would be helpful to retrofit curved arms on the hinges in option B to help clearance. Can you evaluate viability and cost/difficulty?
3. Accessing the full width of the cubby seems to be much more important than the full height. For all options, does moving hinges/actuators to the top of the cubby help preserve full width? When open the screen can cover the top half of the cubby. Or how do we avoid using an inner sleeve? 
4. Is the hinged opening mechanism for option B mechanized?

Thanks again
Gotcha, I’ll bubble it up again in my response to Rob
Just need info from <@U02E3CRMA>  on the AV and software communication schematic
<@U026103R3>: one of the pieces I’m generating today for the TDD update
I’ll make sure it gets done first
perfect, thanks
another thing to remember is that the thickness decreases quite a bit when you take off the AD22 metal backplate... down to about 1.5" or so
here, I found some notes: "detached front panel is about 40mm thick and maybe 12 pounds"

<@U02F8LF2X>: does it make sense for you to jump on a thread and remind them of these details? i want to make sure you’re driving that particular conversation and that we’re not waiting on them to prod
<@U02F8LF2X>: heyyy josh, given Rob’s latest response can you follow up and ask about the possibility of removing the backplate?
actually hang tight
i’ll just queue it up
I have notes about the mechanicals from our planar visit
they're in that shared google doc joel started
cool, i’ll just ask in this email and if he has questions i’ll defer to you guys
